content.description:
Just what I was looking for: a chance to spray about Dave Fields. Dave put up many of the routes on North Table Mountain back when it just looked like a choss pile. The crags don't look much better several years down the line, but a slew of fine climbing routes have arisen from the heap. Winter Warmer is certainly one of the best lines on the hill and a fine contribution on Dave's part.

The climbing begins below the tallest sector of the hill, and takes a bold stab up the headwall 65 feet above. Start in a flaring, inverted slot and make a big reach to killer jugs and the second clip. The bigger your ape index, the easier the move.  Winter Warmer steps left to follow a line of bolts up to the roof and head wall above. A variation to Winter Warmer stays straight on after the second clip and follows a thin seam for a short way. This is also a fine route, and it is also 80 - 85 feet long. Pull the roof on Winter Warmer on its left hand side and continue up a pumpy jug haul to the double bolt anchor that is over a ledge and out of sight.

Three stars by any estimate for the nice long route, good climbing moves, boldness, and overall fine stone.
content.protection: QDs only. Bring a bunch of draws. This route is 80 - 85 feet long and is well-bolted but bold. The route needs a 60 m rope. This will get you down with a bit to spare, but a 50 m rope will not. Watch out! I have watched people get lowered off a 50 m rope to pick up a nasty fall at the end.  As of 2007, the bolts have been updated.

content.description:
This is the bolted line just to the right of

Slot to Trot

.  You can recognize it by the big death flake right of the 2nd bolt.  You can clip the 3rd from standing on it (don't knock it off on your belayer).  The 4th bolt is way out of line with the natural line.  It can be replaced with a small nut in a thin crack, or a cam in the bigger crack to the left.  There is one last bolt and a steep crank to the anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a couple small nuts or (#3 Camalot).
content.location:
This is just right of

Slot to Trot

. It is the last route before the Twelve Pack Wall.

climbs.name: Wagoner's Way
climbs.fa: Ken Trout and Kirk Miller, June 26, 2009

content.description:
No box to check for headpoint. Doing

Winter Warmer

with natural pro, ground up, after using bolts to test pro on earlier investigations.  We gave a name to make it easier to communicate a worthy tradventure amongst friends.  We named it after the inventor and supplier of Aliens, Dave Wagoner.  This route is all about the blue and tiny purple Aliens. (Colorado Custom Hardware rocks!)
content.protection: Twenty five pieces were placed for protection.  Pro placed for the runout headwall was blind, reachy, and insecure.  X rated if a fall is taken off the headwall because the gear under the roof is behind fallible-looking, rounded blocks.  Have lots of small Aliens; purple (5), blue (7-8), green (3-4), and one yellow/gray offset Alien for the first piece.  A set of Black Diamond's Steel Nuts, Stoppers, smaller C4 Camalots, and tons of long/ medium runners were used, too.

content.description: This climb was bolted generously, because it is long, steep, and a little bit rotten; hence the name.
content.protection: You'll need a 70 meter rope and 16 draws to reach the triple Winch Hook anchors (clip & go convenience).  Ring anchors have also been installed on the ledge 12 meters up, after the first two bolts, to accommodate parties with shorter ropes.
content.location:
This lies to the right of

Winter Warmer

.

climbs.name: Stickin' It To The Man
climbs.fa: Tim Slater,  Ken & Marsha Trout, Kirk Miller,  and Jeroen van Wolferen

content.description:
This route climbs the arete right of

Winter Warmer

.  Begin with stemming up the bolted crack just right of

Winter Warmer

.  The route has gray hangers, shares no bolts with

Winter Warmer

, and is closely bolted.  This is the easiest long pitch at Table. Steep too!  Like all routes here, watch out for loose holds.

It is still possible to do Winter Warmer Right, but this means using some of the bolts on the new, discrete, Stick It To The Man.
content.protection: Ken drilled the twelve bolts and beefed up the anchor too.  Then we did the FA party-style with friends and family.
content.location:
This is the next route right of

Winter Warmer

and left of

No Gumbies

and

Ugly Stick

.  The anchor is the same as Winter Warmer Right.

content.description:
Climb the start of

Ugly Stick

through its crux, clipping 9 or 10 bolts, and step right to a good rest in an alcove. Clip an overhead bolt up and right to protect a fun, airy pull out of the alcove right. Another bolt protects the stand up and traverse right to finish on

Chossy Achievers

.
content.protection: Two bolts protect the traverse. Long slings help with rope drag. A 70 meter rope and 16 or 17 bolts get you to the chain anchors.
content.location:
This variation connects the

Ugly Stick

start to finish on the

Chossy Achievers

headwall.

content.description:
Eds.

This description was added to increase the information provided.  This route is a sport climb up a very smooth-appearing face with virtually no holds.  From its appearance from the ground, it looks nearly impossible to climb.  Apparently, there are holds.  Kudos to the first ascentionist in sending it.  Early on, there was a broken hold which was apparently glued back on.
content.protection: QDs only. This 40 foot route needs 5 draws and something for the double bolt anchor at the top.

content.description: Hand & finger jams get you through through the slot and onto a large block.  Face climb past five bolts above to the anchors.
content.protection: Wires and cams to 2" protect the slot leading to five bolts and a chain anchor.
content.location:
Slot to Trot is approximately 10 yards right of

Solar Panel

, left of

Unknown?

.

content.description:
This burly variation takes the crack and face to the top of

Cool Water Sandwich

without stemming to the left wall.
content.protection: 8 bolts.
content.location:
This is a variation to finish

Cool Water Sandwich

.

content.description:
This route is kind of fun, but it gets no stars in the Haas/Schneider guidebook. It is a way to climb most of

Polar Sandals

without doing its crux. The rock contains some lichen in this area, but it is not too bad. If you want to finish on

Polar Sandals

, bring 10 quickdraws. There is no webbing on a horn after the first 5.7 section as described by Haas/Schneider. The last 15 feet up to the

Solar Panel

anchor is the crux.
content.protection:
A standard rack up to a #3 Camalot and 1 bolt. The anchors on

Solar Panel

are to the right or up to the left on

Polar Sandals

.
content.location:
This route is just to the left of

Polar Sandals

and to the right of

Ascending Order

. You can get down from the

Solar Panel

anchors or the

Polar Sandals

anchor if you join it.

content.description:
Polar Sandals is a new 35 meter climb at Table. Thanks to Kirk for equipping this line.

Start up the thin dihedral, then make cool moves (cruxy) left to the face of the "pillar". Slab it out for a couple bolts to a rest. There is some moderate climbing to a sweet mantle and another rest. Move left, and blast to the top on steep rock. Finish with an easy runout to the anchors. This has good movement, with upper and lower cruxes. I hope this cleans up as nicely as

Ugly Stick

.

PLEASE WATCH FOR LOOSE ROCK AS THIS CLEANS UP.
content.protection:
A 70 meter rope is required.

16 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with ring and chains to lower or rappel.

Gear can protect the start, before the first clip: a #3 Camalot down low, and either a #1 or 0.75 just higher.
content.location:
This is on the Winter Warmer Wall, just left of

Solar Panel

.

content.description: No Gumbies climbs the slab above the small roof where the first bolt is located.  Small edges lead to an overhanging face just below the anchors.  The crux is well protected.
content.protection:
4 bolts.  A #0.75 Camalot can be placed between the first two bolts in the

Fenced In

crack to the left.  A small cam or nut can also be placed above the second bolt.  With bolts only, this route would deserve an "R" rating.  There is a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route is located between

Ugly Stick

and

Fenced In

.

content.description: NIMBY starts with crux moves clipping, and moving past, the first bolt.  A second bolt is clipped once you are on easier ground. (Now there are 7 bolts.)  Move up the steep face above and place gear before pulling over a small roof onto a good stance.  From here, a somewhat runout but easy (5.7) slab with good horizontal edges is climbed to the anchors.
content.protection: Seven bolts and you formerly needed a rack including nuts and cams to a #1 Camalot. (You needed gear before the addition of 5 bolts). There is a two bolt anchor on top.
content.location:
This route is the second route left of

Winter Warmer

, immediately left of

Pass the Basalt

.  You can see the routes only two bolts (now 7 bolts)  easily from the ground.  Lower off a two bolt anchor at the top.

content.description:
I am surprised this one isn't in the database. The old approach (grappling up the barb wire fence dumped one close to the routes in the area loosely described as the "Fence Area".

As sport climb goes, this one was pretty sporty. I wasn't using a clip stick in those days, so I thought getting to the first clip was pretty bold. This was around '93 so things might have changed a bit.

Cool route! Maybe KT or RW, or RA can supply some FA info.

Per

Mike Gilbert

: This route was a lot of fun and very powerful (or more likely I'm weak.) The route is easy to spot because there are three fairly low bolts within 6 feet of one another. The route is well protected throughout and possibly even slightly over bolted. It starts with a series of difficult bouldery moves and a low crux. Around the halfway point, the feet are very sparse which got me to do a fun but very dynamic move. From the crux, it eases up a little and then a lot as you get closer to the top. There is a set of anchors, a large bulge, and then another set of anchors, but I didn't see the bolts in between (if there were any).
content.protection: 3 bolts; scary getting to first one (c. '93?).
content.location:
It is in the Fence Area (NTM, in same area as

Electrocuticles

.

content.description:
This is the second pitch continuation of

Basalt and Battery

.  The crux is some power crimping 1/3 the way up the pitch.
content.protection: Bolts.

content.description: The crux comes right away.  The groove you fight up IS gruesome.  If you can figure it out, you'll be warmed up for the steep and easier (but sustained) climbing above.  Don't worry if the start stops you, you can avoid the crux on the left and move back to the 2nd bolt.  This brings the overall difficulty down into the 10 range.
content.protection: 11 bolts, 3 bolt anchor with hooks.
content.location:
This route is just left of

Winter Warmer

.

climbs.name: G-Spot (originally submitted as Power of Tower)

content.description: Not really a "sport" climb. There are only 2 bolts (don't blow the 2nd clip).  There are some gear placements before the first bolt, but they are not that inspiring.  This is the R part, but only 5.9ish. Above the roof there is plenty of gear options (if needed).  The crux is moving up to, then over the roof....
content.protection: 2 bolts, some small gear, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
Power is just right of

G-Spot

, which is right of the obvious

Solar Panel

.

content.description:
This is a great climb immediately to the right of

Solar Panel

.  Start up an easy face, to a prominent thin crack which takes TCUs. Above this crack, you will see a roof with one bolt on it.  I gave it an S rating, as the pro between these two points is hard to come by, besides a few tricky nut placements.  Above the roof the climbing eases to a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Wires to #4 Friend.

content.description: The route climbs the obvious chimney.  At its top, break left to a layback crack.  The chimney looks a bit dirty, but it's not too bad and has some interesting hidden holds.  The layback crack is great although a little short.
content.protection: Standard rack to a #4 Camalot.
content.location:
Foul Play is 10 feet right of

Electrocuticles

.

Descend from the

Electrocuticles

anchor.

content.description:
This crack is ascended with a combination of stemming and face holds.  With the exception of one hand jam at the bottom, I did not use the crack except for gear.  The crack is about #0.75 Camalot sized its entire length. At the top of the crack, a bolt can be clipped on

Stickin' it to the Man

to protect the chossy, rightward moves to the anchor.  I placed a #3 and #4 Camalot slightly higher than the bolt.  This is a good route with the exception of the last 10 feet where the rock quality deteriorates.
content.protection:
4 bolts on

Stickin' it to the Man

and cams up to a #4 Camalot.  Small nuts.
content.location:
This route climbs the crack and right-facing dihedral to the left of

No Gumbies

.  It shares a start with

Stickin' it to the Man

but veers right at this route's 3rd clip.  Use the anchors on

No Gumbies

to descend.

content.description:
This is located 50 feet+ to the right of

Winter Warmer

, this is the large open book starting about 15 feet off the ground.

We did this route using the crack in the back of the dihedral (5.10a) it is apparently 5.10c if you don't use the crack.  This climb feels a lot bigger than it looks once you get up into the dihedral.  You can get an all-day rest half way up by putting your back on the right wall and your feet just below the tiny roof.  It is a very trad route except for the bolts!

F.A.T.A.L. = Femurs And Tibias Alternating Laterally.
content.protection:
4 bolts plus a 2 bolt anchor.

Eds. This was originally submitted having 5 bolts.

content.description:
Electrocuticles begins at the point where the broken fence just meets the wall. This excellent line fires up a nearly black and nearly blank wall about 60 feet to the right of

Winter Warmer

and a bit left of the

Solar Panel

. Negotiate a reachy jug haul to stand on micro feet below the black wall. A few tricky moves on the arete lead to a clip that almost provides a top rope for the crux. Suck in your breath after the crux, 5.12a, for a dicey run out to more jugs, another clip or two and the anchor. Electrocuticles gets two stars for for rock, the continuity, and the tricky moves. This stuff is thin by Table Mountain standards and the climbing is very technical. Nice job and a nice eye by the FA team.
content.protection: QD only. This 50 foot route has 5 lead bolts and a double bolt anchor with mussy hooks for lowering off.

content.description:
Hop up some ledges til you reach a really sharp layback crack.  If only this was much longer, it would be a classic.  Make a couple layback moves, be careful of the loose part of the flake, mantle onto a ledge and cruise the blocky crack to the top of the

Basalt and Battery

pinnacle.
content.protection: A couple mid-size cams (#1-#2).
content.location:
This is the left-facing corner to the left of

Basalt and Battery

.  You can step down to that anchor to get off.

climbs.name: Cool Water Sandwich
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Luke Winkelbauer, Troy Tadlock

content.description:
Pull into the shallow dihedral, climb to the ledge, and stem your way to the anchors.

The direct variation, Rubber Biscuit, climbs the crack and face, without stemming to the left wall and goes at 5.11.
content.protection: Eight bolts to chains.
content.location:
This is 50 feet right of

Slot To Trot

.

content.description:
Climb the slot with small cams and a few nuts to the belay ledge on

Ugly Stick

.  Climb the crack in the face right of

Ugly Stick

protected by more wires and small cams.  When the crack runs out, the real choss begins, but so do the bolts; all the way to the rim.
content.protection:
A 70m rope, slings, wires and cams to gold Camalot.  Doubles in the smaller sizes help. Nine bolts to get you through the chossness, to chain anchors.

Take care with a heads up belay, and be sure to wear the helmets for this one.
content.location:
This route starts in the shallow slot just right of

Ugly Stick

, left of

Crash Test Blondes

.

content.description:
This is a great route usually away from the crowds.  It can be a long two pitch climb if you add "

Insult and Flatterly

, 12c," to it.  Note the second pitch has some bolts that are bad and missing.  The first pitch is nice and feels committing as you approach the ledge where the anchors are.  This climb is located in the fence area to the far right of "

Winter Warmer

" climb.
content.protection:
Quickdraws to a two bolt anchor above ledge. This is an established route, so check bolts.

Addendum:

thin gear may be useful around the 1st bolt.

Per

Mark Rolofson

: this was originally done with 3 bolts and gear.

content.description: The crux is the transition from stem to arete.  Be careful not to break the loose foot hold while making the first clip.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This route is in between

Basalt and Battery

and

Klimbink is Ferbolten

, and it shares the

Basalt

anchor.

climbs.name: Ascending Order
climbs.fa: Jeremy Bilewski, Hannah Grossman, Kirk Miller

content.description:
Keep to the left in the

POS Dihedral

, and climb to the diving board with the wedged old white tat. Surmount the diving board, and a nice hand crack will take you to the first bolt. Climb onto the block above and follow the bolts up the scoop. Climb up right onto another large block and clip two more bolts to reach the offwidth.
content.protection: The gear goes pretty much in ascending order: thinner placements down low to a #1 and a #3 Camalot for the hand crack.   Draws for six bolts then a #2 Camalot gets you started into the wide.  A few #4s and a #5 Camalot protect the offwidth.   Bolted anchors with chains greet you at the top.
content.location:
Ascending Order is a continuation to the rim of one of the old

POS Dihedral

variations. Located left of

Polar Sandals

, it climbs the left wall of the dihedral via a nice hand crack and finishes in the offwidth high above.
